0: Image caption The Free Syrian Army and other rebel fighters have been engaged in fierce fighting in Aleppo NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR US Defence Secretary Leon Panetta says Syrian President Bashar al-Assad's assault on the city of Aleppo will be "a nail in his coffin". NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Mr Panetta was speaking at the start of a five-day Middle East tour. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Heavy fighting is continuing in Syria's largest city where government forces are trying to oust rebel fighters. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR UN humanitarian chief Valerie Amos said 200,000 people had fled the fighting in Aleppo and that an unknown number were trapped. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR She said that the city urgently needed supplies including food and water. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Mr Panetta said the Syrian crisis was deepening and that President Assad was hastening his own demise. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "If they continue this kind of tragic attack on their own people... I think it ultimately will be a nail in Assad's coffin," he told reporters. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "What Assad has been doing to his own people and what he continues to do to his own people makes clear that his regime is coming to an end. It's lost all legitimacy." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR He added: "It's no longer a question of whether he's coming to an end, it's when." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR At the scene A hole-in-the-wall bakery had just reopened its doors after being closed for more than a day. Most food shops in the turbulent districts are now closed. Rebel fighters tried to marshal the crowds as hundreds of hungry and increasingly desperate residents clamoured for the thin round loaves. Suriya had finally reached the front of the queue and the middle-aged mother thrust her hand through the railings outside the bakery, grasping for the bread. Like many poor Syrians she has a large family to feed and with no fresh fruit or vegetables available this is her only chance to get food. "A lot of poor people are suffering from a lack of food and water," she complained. "Many are going to bed hungry." Their suffering does not seem likely to end soon. Food, water and power shortages have made life hard for residents. The ever-present danger from bombs and bullets is making it intolerable. Fear and hunger in Aleppo NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Mr Panetta's tour will include talks in Tunisia, Egypt, Israel and Jordan. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR He said he aimed to reinforce an international consensus that Mr Assad must step down and allow a peaceful transition to democracy. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The defence secretary said he would also continue efforts to ensure that Syria's stockpiles of chemical weapons did not fall into the wrong hands. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Baroness Amos, speaking in New York, said that the Red Cross and the Syrian Arab Red Crescent estimated that 200,000 people have fled Aleppo and surrounding areas in the past two days. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "It is not known how many people remain trapped in places where fighting continues today," she said. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "I call on all parties to the fighting to ensure that they do not target civilians and that they allow humanitarian organisations safe access." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR UK-based activist group the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights described the situation in Aleppo as "a full-scale street war". NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The BBC's Ian Pannell, who was in Aleppo on Saturday, said government troops were trying to push into rebel-held neighbourhoods and there was fierce fighting. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Civilians are facing power cuts and food shortages, he says. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Late on Sunday, Syrian troops said they had recaptured the south-west district of Salah al-Din from the rebels. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "Complete control of Salah al-Din has been (won back) from those mercenary gunmen," a military officer told Syrian state TV. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "In a few days safety and security will return to the city of Aleppo." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Despite the army's statement, activists said fighting was continuing in Salah al-Din on Sunday night. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Aleppo activist Abo Aref al-Halabi told the BBC's Newsday programme on Monday that it had been a "terrible night" in the city. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "Nobody can sleep. Everywhere you can hear [the sound of] bombs," he said. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "The Assad armies are using mortars, they are using tanks, bombs, they are using helicopters, missiles coming from helicopters, to the Salah al-Din area." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR He said some buildings were on fire and others had collapsed. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Battle-hardened NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Our correspondent says that although the rebels are outgunned, they are fighting an effective guerrilla war in the streets of the city. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Many are more battle-hardened than their adversaries and they are making their own improvised explosive devices, he adds. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Syrian Foreign Minister Walid Moualem, on a visit to Iran, said that the government was winning its war
